messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai and Knights
messages.msgSnippet: I know.They had completely different weapons and armour.The knights used normal,straight swords while the Japanese used their specially curved katana....Edy
messages.messageBody:
I know.They had completely different weapons and armour.The knights used normal,straight swords while the Japanese used their specially curved katana....Edy

Josh Wilson <lordwilson@...> wrote:The developement of arms and armour was totaly different as were the theories and pinciples behind using the weapons...

Wilson

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai and Knights
messages.msgSnippet: I don t think that it s necessarily a bad assignment as long as the teacher acknowledges that analogizing the samurai and European knights is an outdated
messages.messageBody:
I don't think that it's necessarily a bad assignment as long as the teacher
acknowledges that analogizing the samurai and European knights is an
outdated analysis. Seems to me a ripe opportunity to illustrate how the
historiographic process works (over time) and the necessity of reading
one's sources critically. Might be nice to (capitalizing on what many
students bring to introductory classes in the way of baggage) 1) assign
this topic, 2) have them read some excerpts from _Bushido_ by Nitobe, and
then 3) read G. Cameron (Cappy) Hurst's article on Bushido, Loyalty, etc.

My point being that it is not necessarily a bad topic if approached
properly.

-Shannon

Tom Helm wrote:

All-
We have to locate the teacher who is giving this assignment and shut
him down...
-t
